title-group.article-title: Pure Pancreatic-Type Acinar Cell Carcinoma of the Stomach
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report

author-notes.corresp: John D. Coyne, Royal Liverpool Hospital, Prescott Street, Liverpool, L7 8XP, UK Email: johnnycoyne@doctors.org.uk

abstract.p: Acinar cell carcinoma is an uncommon carcinoma of the exocrine pancreas. On very rare occasions it has been reported in ectopic sites, sometimes with, but usually without contiguous heterotopic pancreatic tissue. Whilst mixed and composite glandular tumours have also been described, pure pancreatic-type acinar cell carcinomas arising in the stomach are very rare.

body.p: Cases of primary pancreatic-type acinar cell carcinoma arising in ectopic sites have been reported in both pure and mixed forms.1-11 In its pure form, however, only 7 previous cases have been documented,1,3,5,7-9,11 3 of which were described within the stomach.5,7,11 This article records only the fourth such case.

A 77-year-old woman had a gastroscopy as part of the investigation of anemia. A large lobulated mass projecting from the fundus was noted. An initial biopsy showed focal intestinal metaplasia but no evidence of malignancy, and the second biopsy was reported as poorly differentiated carcinoma. Abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography scan showed no gross or metastatic lesions elsewhere. The patient had a partial gastrectomy but died a month later of complications. Macroscopically, a well-circumscribed 4.5 × 3.5 cm tumor, polypoid and exophytic in appearance was present beneath a focally ulcerated but largely intact mucosa. Microscopic examination showed the submucosal carcinoma to be composed of cells with a solid and focally acinar appearance (Figure 1). In a few areas, a trabecular pattern was noted. Most of the cells had abundant, granular eosinophilic cytoplasm but in places the cytoplasm was clear or basophilic (Figure 2). Nuclei were generally bland with small nucleoli. In places, however, there was more severe atypia with larger nucleoli and prominent mitotic activity. One focus showing severe atypia was present and at this point, the tumor cells infiltrated the overlying muscularis mucosa (Figure 3). Mitotic figures were infrequent but in the few atypical areas, numbered approximately 3 per 10 high-power fields. Immunohistochemistry showed strong, diffuse positivity with trypsin and alpha-1 antitrypsin, focal moderate positivity with CD56 and weak, diffuse positivity with synaptophysin and pancreatic polypeptide (Figure 4). CK7 and 20, chromogranin, serotonin, insulin, alpha-foetoprotein, and glucagon were negative. Ultrastructural examination showed cells with small, round, dense exocrine granules with occasional larger pleomorphic zymogen-type granules (Figure 5). Large amounts of rough endoplasmic reticulum were also present.

body.p: Pure primary pancreatic-type acinar cell carcinomas arising in ectopic locations are rare. Three cases have been reported to occur in the stomach,5,7,11 and 3 cases have been reported in the liver, the colon, and in a mediastinal teratoma.3,8,9

In addition, 2 cases of mixed acinar endocrine cell carcinoma occurring in the stomach have been reported.4,10 One histologically resembled pure acinar cell carcinoma but showed a mixed acinar/endocrine immunophenotype with alpha-foetoprotein reactivity10; the other had morphologically distinct acinar and endocrine components.4 Makhlouf et al2 documented a mixed pancreatic acinar and ductal carcinoma arising in jejunal pancreatic heterotopia. The 3 cases of composite glandular and endocrine tumors with acinar differentiation reported arising in the stomach make up a distinct but different type of primary gastric carcinoma with pancreatic differentiation.10

The occurrence of pancreatic tissue in the stomach can be metaplastic or heterotopic.11 The former is sometimes associated with autoimmune gastritis and usually mucosal in location. Heterotopic pancreatic tissue is more frequently submucosal and is present in the pyloroantral region.11 The previous 3 cases of pure primary gastric acinar cell carcinoma as well as the current case were entirely or predominantly submucosal. The one case associated with benign pancreatic tissue displayed metaplastic pancreatic tissue in the overlying mucosa.3 Consequently, tumor metaplasia or origin from a pluripotential endodermal stem cell may be the pathogenetic mechanism for this rare tumor occurrence.
In conclusion, this is the fourth reported case of primary, pancreatic-type acinar cell carcinoma arising in the stomach.
